newsitem.title: BAHRAIN: Arab states plan projects worth $1.4 billion.
newsitem.headline: Arab states plan projects worth $1.4 billion.

text.p: Arab states plan to set up three factories to produce iron, steel and industrial refractory for a total cost of $1.4 billion, an Arab official said on Tuesday.
Mohammed Karbid, general manager of the Rabat-based Arab Industrial Development & Mining Organisation (AIDMO) said Arab financial institutions would finance these projects.

Karbid, speaking to reporters in Bahrain where he attended a two-day conference on petrochemicals in the Arab world, said studies were under way to build a $1 billion plant in Mauritania to produce four million tonnes of iron pellets a year.
AIDMO, owned by all Arab states, chose Mauritania because of huge reserves of more than one billion tonnes of raw material needed for the plant.
Karbid said AIDMO was studying plans to build a similar $300 million plant in the Gulf, possibly in Saudi Arabia, to produce between 200,000 to 250,000 tonnes a year.
The giant Saudi Basic Industries Corp (SABIC) has helped make the kingdom the biggest petrochemical producer in the Middle East.
SABIC, 70 percent owned by the Saudi government, accounts for around five percent of the world's total petrochemical output.

Karbid said AIDMO was also looking at plans to build a $120 million plant in Morocco to produce 300,000 tonnes a year of industrial refractory -- a substance mainly used in lining furnaces because of its ability to resist high temperatures.
He said work had already begun on another $320 million project in Egypt to manufacture special steel to produce around 275,000 tonnes a year.
